reviews.text: This hotel is very close to S. Maria delle Grazie church, where there Is the famous Leonardo's Last Supper. The hotel is located in an old monastery and it maintains the cloister (now a space for exhibition) and the calm. The rooms on the cloister side are very quiet and full of light, even if the impossibility of opening the windows makes them a little claustrophobic. The room furniture Is poor and the bathroom absolutely unfit to. "big" people. Generally speaking, rooms represent the worst part of this venue that, for the rest, is really nice. Good restaurant in the former Leonardo's potager (menus from 26 to 38 euros and a la carte), cheap salade bar. The location is fine for reaching the city center by subway. Possibility of reduced fee. Price around 180 euros for a double room, international breakfast included.
reviews.title: In the shadow of Leonardo

reviews.text: I have been spending several times 1-2 nights in this place. It is perfectly located in the center of Milan and all touristic places are in walking distance. The Last Supper is just on the other side of the road by the way. The building has splendid arches and a nice inner courtyard. As to the rooms and the hotel part of it I mostly feel like in a youth hostel: very old fashioned furniture and a minimal service (the bar closed at 18h00) . You are asked out of the breakfast room on Sunday at 10 h sharp.
reviews.title: Milano from a cloister

reviews.text: The staff at this hotel were very nice, but my room, a deluxe single, reeked of smoke, had no blanket (only a paper-thin coverlet) and was actually on two levels. Don't believe for a second that this place has any character because of its situation inside a converted convent. The insides are like an American motel. One nice thing, however, is that as a conference hotel, there is a bar and a restuarant onsite. I am sure that the food isn't very good, but if it was pouring rain or you just wanted to grab somethign and get back to work in your room it would be fine. Good location for the Castle and the Duomo, and for the Catholic University.
reviews.title: Absolutely average, like a motel inside an old convent!

reviews.text: I arrived in Milan with a reservation at a different hotel that turned out to be such a dump I had to scramble to find something on the spur of the moment. I called the Hotel Palazzo delle Steline and they were incredibly accommodating. Although they could only guarantee me a room for the first night out of the four I needed, the friendly desk staff assured me that if they couldn't accommodate me, they would find me someplace nearby, so that I didn't have to do all the calling myself. In the end, I was able to stay all four nights, and I was very glad I did.
reviews.title: incredibly helpful staff

reviews.text: As some of the other reviews have noted, the hotel is rather lacking in character, being part of a conference center. Walking around at night was a bit odd, as there were never any people in the large spaces for the conference center. But my room was very large, clean, with nice ameneties (fridge, safe) and a nice view. Breakfast was very good, with great variety. It was located in a good part of town, near the center, but far enough away that it was nice a quiet.

reviews.text: Anyway, the Palazzo is lovely. Part museum, with conference facilities and a café (though it closes early, which is a shame, as the only other space to wait for a colleague or partner is the reception). It's a splendid space. But the rooms are awful – like worn-out motel rooms. Carpets old and dirty, furniture from the 1970s. And the toilets in the bathroom have a flush button, which you have to turn off yourself. A guest in a room beneath us hadn't sussed this one out, so the toilet flushed loudly for over 20 minutes in the night. Very noisy.
reviews.title: Good experience

reviews.text: Now, I don't mind exercise, but don't book this hotel if you're elderly or infirm, as the rooms are very far from the reception. 247 paces, in fact – we were on the second floor. And the breakfast room is on the opposite side of the large inner courtyard of the rooms, so another ca. 200 paces.

reviews.text: This is not a standard, commercial hotel. It is uniquely configured around a large courtyard, with rooms facing both inwards and outwards. Its main function seems to be a congress centre, and is frequently busy doing that. The reception staff are efficient but aloof. It charges 5euros per hour for internet wifi! But this was the third time my wife and I have stayed there and it still seems attractive to us. This time we had a room (standard price) that was a mini-suite, with a sitting/working area and semi-detached bedroom. The bathrooms are small - planned by a dwarf architect it seems - and now looking a bit tired. They need modernising and enlarging. Conveniently located (especially for Malpensa Express train to/from Cadorno station, 5 minutes walk away) - not in the centre, but with bars, restaurants and shops nearby.
reviews.title: Convenient and comfortable
